LAKE DRAPER WATER TREATMENT PLANT,
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN/PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMP/PSMP)
MARCH 2012
X
Executive Summary
Lake Draper Water Treatment Plant (WTP) has adopted this Risk Management Program in order to implement 40 CFR 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals. This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.
This Executive Summary includes information required under 40 CFR 68.155.
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The City of Oklahoma City Utilities Department implements a scheduled preventive maintenance program, including inspection and testing, to minimize the potential for accidental releases. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work safely and efficiently and provide immediate corrective response to any accidents.
The Lake Draper WTP staff are trained to respond in the event of a chemical release incident. Emergency response to accidental releases is also coordinated with the Oklahoma City Police and Fire Departments and the State and Local Emergency Response Centers.
Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances
The Lake Draper WTP utilizes chlorine and anhydrous ammonia (regulated substances) as disinfectants in the drinking water treatment process.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
A Process Hazard Analysis as well as written process safety information has been developed to enable personnel to identify and understand the hazar

ds posed by processes involving highly hazardous chemicals. Process safety information includes chlorine and anhydrous ammonia information, technology of the process information, and equipment information.
The City of Oklahoma City Utilities Engineering Division verifies that City owned water and wastewater treatment plants comply with applicable codes and standards and with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices (through review of engineering standards for construction projects).
The Process Hazard Analysis completed for this RMP documents the process and the findings to minimize or eliminate hazards, to mitigate the consequences of hazards of any releases or other unplanned events, and to reduce the likelihood of exposure to chlorine or anhydrous ammonia.
Written procedures and information have been developed, implemented, and maintained for each hazardous process, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.
All employees involved in working with and around the chlorine and anhydrous ammonia systems are trained in process and safety procedures, including emergency response on an annual basis.
The mechanical integrity of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia process equipment is documented and maintained through maintenance, inspection, and testing programs. In addition, a Management of Change program has been established to ensure proper review of a proposed change to the chlorine or anhydrous ammonia systems.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN/PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMP/PSMP)
MARCH 2012
XI
A pre-startup safety review is performed on new or modified processes to ensure that equipment and construction meet design specifications, procedures and training have been implemented, and hazard analysis recommendations have been resolved.
A Compliance Audit Program has also been implemented. The objective of this self-evaluation p

rogram is to ensure that a strong RMP program is maintained, implemented, and followed by appropriate personnel.
Staff have developed a formal documented system to manage incident investigations and follow up. Each incident that results in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of chlorine or anhydrous ammonia in the workplace will be investigated and an incident investigation report filed in the RMP.
Lake Draper WTP Management staff are committed to involving employees, or their representatives, in supporting the elements of the RMP/PSMP. The following elements involve employee participation regarding the RMP/PSMP:
¿h Involve employees in the PHA, Compliance Audits, and RMP/PSMP reviews and updates
¿h Provide employee access to the RMP/PSMP
¿h Present an overview of RMP/PSMP requirements to staff annually
¿h Involve employees in the development and updating of training
¿h Involve employees in an incident investigation
An authorization and permit program for hot work operations near or around the regulated chlorine and anhydrous ammonia processes has been implemented at the WTP.
Contractors performing maintenance or repair on or adjacent to chlorine or anhydrous ammonia processes are instructed in the hazards of the materials on site, and documentation is maintained on contractor understanding of training provided as described in the RMP/PSMP. In addition, emphasis is placed on knowing how to respond in event of emergency.
The WTP chlorine and anhydrous ammonia system technologies are not confidential and any information regarding the process or process chemistry is available for review in the RMP.
Five-Year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases within the past 5 years from the covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage.
Emergency Response Program
The RMP Emergency Response Plan for the WTP includes the following elements:
¿h Procedures

for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases
¿h Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures
¿h Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated substance
¿h Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance
¿h Training for all employees in relevant procedures
¿h Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes at the stationary source and ensure that employees are informed of changes
A copy of emergency procedures are maintained at the location for chlorine and anhydrous ammonia stationary sources. WTP personnel are trained to take action to control a minor release. Trained personnel will attempt to control a release within their capability. However, in the event that the release is beyond the control of the operators, they would immediately notify the Fire Department.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The WTP planned changes to improve safety include conducting a review of RMP elements on an annual basis and discussions of RMP/PSMP topics quarterly in Safety Meetings.
